titles.title: To amend the Consumer Product Safety Act to provide that low-speed electric bicycles are consumer products subject to such Act.

action.text: Referred to the House Committee on Energy and Commerce.
Committee Consideration and Mark-up Session Held.

committee.name: House Committee on Energy and Commerce

calendar.text: Ordered to be Reported by Voice Vote.

committee.name: House Committee on Energy and Commerce

action.text: Reported by the Committee on Energy and Commerce. H. Rept. 107-5.

calendar.text: Placed on the Union Calendar, Calendar No. 4.

action.text: Mr. Stearns moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
DEBATE - The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 727.

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.

vote.text: On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: (2/3 required): 401 - 1 (Roll no. 27).

action.text: Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
Received in the Senate and Read twice and referred to the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation.
Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation discharged by Unanimous Consent.

vote.text: Passed Senate without amendment by Unanimous Consent.

action.text: Message on Senate action sent to the House.

bill.summary: 3/5/2001--Reported to House without amendment. Amends the Consumer Product Safety Act (CPSA) to provide that low-speed electric bicycles are consumer products and shall be subject to Consumer Product Safety Commission regulations.Declares that this Act supersedes any State law or requirement regarding such vehicles more stringent than Federal law or requirements.States that, for purposes of Federal motor vehicle safety standards, a low-speed electric bicycle as defined by CPSA shall not be considered to be a motor vehicle within the ambit of Federal transportation law.
